secret_rule: Only items that are typically associated with renowned landmark court cases or legal precedents can be brought to the picnic.

conversation.content: To start, here are some examples of items you can bring: "Miranda warning card" and "Brown v. Board of Education textbook".

Given the two examples provided by the Game Master - a "Miranda warning card" and a "Brown v. Board of Education textbook" - I notice these are both related to legal/judicial topics. My strategic guess would be to ask about bringing something like a "Supreme Court decision document" to see if it matches the apparent pattern.

So I would ask the Game Master: "Can I bring a Supreme Court decision document to the game?"
Yes, you can bring a Supreme Court decision document.

Based on the examples and the confirmation that a Supreme Court decision document is also allowed, I notice a clear pattern emerging related to legal documents or items from the judicial system.

I'll test this hypothesis by asking about another legal/judicial document: "Can I bring a Constitutional amendment text?"

This guess avoids repeating previous items and explores whether legal/judicial-related documents are indeed the underlying rule.
Yes, you can bring a Constitutional amendment text.

Based on the pattern of accepted items, my final rule guess is:

The rule is: "Bring an item related to law, legal documents, or the judicial system"

My reasoning:
1. Accepted items so far:
- Miranda warning card (a legal procedural document)
- Brown v. Board of Education textbook (a landmark Supreme Court case)
- Supreme Court decision document (a legal judicial record)
- Constitutional amendment text (a foundational legal document)

2. All these items share a common theme of being connected to law, legal processes, court systems, or constitutional matters.

3. The rule seems to require the item to have a substantive connection to legal/judicial topics, not just a superficial or tangential relationship.

My guess represents what appears to be a consistent underlying pattern across the accepted examples - a focus on legal and judicial documentary or reference materials.
